description:
Chanodichthys erythropterus, commonly known as the redfin culter, is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the family Cultrinae. It is native to the Yangtze River basin in China.

The Chanodichthys erythropterus is a medium-sized fish, typically reaching a length of around 30-40 cm. It has an elongated, streamlined body shape, which is characteristic of the culter fish group. The most distinctive feature of this species is its reddish-orange fins, particularly the dorsal and anal fins, which give it the common name "redfin culter."

This species is an omnivorous fish, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, small invertebrates, and even small fish. It is an important component of the freshwater ecosystems in its native range, playing a role in the food web and nutrient cycling.

Chanodichthys erythropterus is of commercial importance in China, where it is widely cultured and harvested for food. However, like many other freshwater fish species, it faces threats from habitat degradation, pollution, and overfishing, which have led to population declines in some areas.
